questions.question: Do you know what an Access Package in Entra ID is?
questions.explanation: An Access Package is a feature in Microsoft Entra ID Governance that allows users to request a predefined set of resources like groups, Teams, SharePoint sites, or apps all at once. It simplifies access management, especially for onboarding, project access, or external users, by automating approvals, expirations, and reviews.

action.text: Learn about Access Packages

questions.question: What license does your organization currently use for Microsoft Entra?
questions.explanation: Access Packages are part of Microsoft Entra ID Governance, which requires the P2 license. Knowing your current license level is essential to determine what features (like access reviews, dynamic assignment, or lifecycle policies) you can use.

answers.label: Microsoft Entra ID Governance Step Up for Microsoft Entra ID Px

questions.question: For which use cases in your company are Access Packages planned?
questions.explanation: Access Packages can be used for a wide range of scenarios: onboarding employees or external users, project-based access, temporary access for contractors, or self-service group access. Understanding your use cases will help design your Access Packages more effectively.

questions.question: What is the authoritative source of truth for your user identities? (i.e., the system from which other directories or apps are synchronized)
questions.explanation: The authoritative source of truth is the primary system where user identities are created and managed often an HR tool or directory like Active Directory. Knowing this helps determine how identities are provisioned and synced into Microsoft Entra ID and ensures that access governance starts from a reliable source.

answers.label: HR Solution (Cloud HR Tool, e.g., Workday, SAP SuccessFactors)

questions.question: Do you have a consistent naming convention in place for your cloud-based groups (e.g., [Dept]-[App]-[AccessLevel])?
questions.explanation: Naming conventions help standardize group names, making it easier to find and assign the correct groups when configuring Access Packages. A clear naming strategy also improves manageability and reduces errors in access assignment.

questions.question: Is the quality of your user data (e.g., department, location, manager) high enough to support automated access decisions?
questions.explanation: Access Packages can use dynamic rules or policies based on user attributes like department, job title, or location. If these values are missing or inaccurate, automated access assignments will be unreliable.

answers.label: Yes – Most key attributes are accurate and consistently filled
Partially – Some attributes are incomplete or outdated

questions.question: How are user identities created in your environment?
questions.explanation: Understanding how user accounts are created helps assess how scalable, consistent, and secure your identity management process is. Automated identity creation (e.g., through HR-driven provisioning or AD sync) reduces errors and supports reliable access lifecycle management.

answers.label: Automatically via sync (e.g., HR system, Entra Connect)

questions.question: Do you have a defined process for managing the full user lifecycle (Joiner, Mover, Leaver)?
questions.explanation: The user lifecycle refers to managing identity and access when users join, change roles or departments, or leave the organization. Having a clear process ensures that users get access quickly when needed and lose it promptly when they leave.

questions.question: Do you support external identities (B2B guests) in your environment?
questions.explanation: Microsoft Entra supports B2B collaboration, allowing external partners or contractors to access resources securely through Access Packages. Supporting guests in a structured way is critical for secure collaboration.

questions.question: Do you use dynamic groups or attribute-based rules to manage group membership?
questions.explanation: Dynamic groups use user attributes (like department, location, or job title) to automatically add or remove users. This enables scalable, accurate group membership and improves automation when assigning Access Packages.

answers.label: Yes - they are governed and monitored
No - I manually assign users to groups

questions.question: Do you require approvals and set expiration dates when users request access to resources (e.g., via Access Packages)?
questions.explanation: Access Packages allow you to define who approves access and how long access is valid. Requiring approvals ensures that only appropriate users gain access. Expiration dates help remove unnecessary access automatically.

answers.label: Yes – We use both approval workflows and time-limited access
Partially – We use either approvals or expiration, not both

questions.question: Have you defined all the necessary ROLES in the company to be able to implement Access Packages?
questions.explanation: To implement Access Packages effectively, it’s important that the necessary roles within your organization are clearly defined. This includes identifying who is responsible for approving access requests, managing the packages, maintaining group memberships, and conducting regular access reviews. Without this clarity, the access management process can become inconsistent, inefficient, or non-compliant.

answers.label: Yes - all important roles are defined
Some - but not all roles are defined

questions.question: Are their ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURES known and set, such as all departments (business units / service units) and locations?
questions.explanation: To manage access effectively with Access Packages, it’s essential to have a clear understanding of your organizational structure including departments, business units, service areas, and physical or regional locations. These structures are often used in dynamic group rules, attribute-based assignments, or policy scopes, so missing or unclear structure data can lead to incorrect access or manual overhead.

answers.label: No - we have things but not documented

action.text: Learn more about Orgnizational Structures

questions.question: Do you know about your compliance and who is responsible for REVIEWING it?
questions.explanation: Understanding your organization's compliance requirements (such as ISO 27001, GDPR, SOX, etc.) is critical for identity and access governance. It’s equally important to know who is responsible for reviewing whether access controls and user permissions meet those standards. This ensures that access packages and entitlement management are aligned with both security policies and audit expectations.

answers.label: Yes - Shared Responsibility Model is defined
